<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">



<!-- link2 "ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="008"></A></DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Forward-Looking Information</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The discussions under Business, Properties and Legal Proceedings and the following discussions
under Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and
Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk contain various forward-looking
statements within the meaning of Section&nbsp;27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section
21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, which represent the Company&#146;s expectations
or beliefs concerning future events. When used in this document and in documents incorporated
herein by reference, the words &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148; &#147;indicates,&#148; &#147;believes,&#148;
&#147;forecast,&#148; &#147;guidance,&#148; &#147;outlook&#148; and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking
statements. Forward-looking statements include, without limitation, the Company&#146;s expectations
concerning operations and financial conditions, including changes in capacity, revenues, and costs,
future financing plans and needs, overall economic conditions, plans and objectives for future
operations, and the impact on the Company of its results of operations in recent years and the
sufficiency of its financial resources to absorb that impact. Other forward-looking statements
include statements which do not relate solely to historical facts, such as, without limitation,
statements which discuss the possible future effects of current known trends or uncertainties, or
which indicate that the future effects of known trends or uncertainties cannot be predicted,
guaranteed or assured. All forward-looking statements in this report are based upon information
available to the Company on the date of this report. The Company undertakes no obligation to
publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information,
future events, or otherwise. The risk factors listed at the end of this Item&nbsp;7 (see Risk Factors),
in addition to other possible risk factors not listed, could cause the Company&#146;s actual results to
differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Overview </B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Company has incurred very large operating and net losses during the past four years, as shown
in the following table:


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="60%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="14" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">Year ended December 31,</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(in millions)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">2004</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">2003</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">2002</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">2001</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Operating loss</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(144</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(844</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(3,330</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(2,470</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Net loss</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">(761</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">(1,228</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">(3,511</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>

    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">(1,762</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">These losses reflect, among other things, a substantial decrease in the Company&#146;s revenues in 2001
and 2002. This revenue decrease was primarily driven by (i)&nbsp;a steep fall-off in the demand for air
travel, particularly business travel, primarily caused by weakness in the U.S. economy, (ii)
reduced pricing power, resulting mainly from greater cost sensitivity on the part of travelers
(especially business travelers), increasing competition from LCCs and the continuing increase in
pricing transparency resulting from the use of the Internet and (iii)&nbsp;the aftermath of the
Terrorist Attacks, which accelerated and exacerbated the trend of decreased demand and reduced
industry revenues. The Company believes that its reduced pricing power resulting from the factors
listed in clause (ii)&nbsp;above will persist indefinitely and possibly permanently.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Passenger traffic rebounded in 2003 and 2004, reflecting a general improvement in the U.S. and
several other economies served by the Company, the diminishing impact of the Terrorist Attacks on
demand and lower fares. However, the Company&#146;s pricing power remained depressed in 2003 due to a
continuation of the factors listed in clause (ii)&nbsp;of the preceding paragraph, and declined in 2004
due to significant increases in overall industry capacity that exceeded the growth in demand, and
more frequent and more deeply discounted fare sales initiated by competitors, including competitors
currently operating under the protection of Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Company&#146;s 2004 operating and financial results were also adversely affected by the significant
increases in the price of jet fuel. Fuel price increases during 2004 resulted in a year-over-year
increase of 33.9 cents per gallon. This price increase negatively impacted fuel expense by $1.1
billion during the year. Continuing high fuel prices, additional increases in the price of fuel,
and/or disruptions in the supply of fuel, would further adversely affect the Company&#146;s financial
condition and its results of operations.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">20
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In response to the challenges faced by the Company, during the past four years the Company has
implemented several restructuring and other initiatives:



<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Following the Terrorist Attacks, the Company reduced its operating
schedule by approximately 20&nbsp;percent and reduced its workforce by
approximately 20,000 jobs.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In 2002, the Company announced a series of initiatives to reduce
its annual costs by $2&nbsp;billion. These initiatives are being
implemented through 2005, and involve: (i)&nbsp;scheduling
efficiencies, (ii)&nbsp;fleet simplification, (iii)&nbsp;streamlined
customer interaction, (iv)&nbsp;distribution modifications, (v)
in-flight product changes, (vi)&nbsp;operational changes and (vii)
headquarters/administration efficiencies. As a result of these
initiatives, the Company reduced an estimated 7,000 jobs by March
2003.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In February&nbsp;2003, American asked its employees for approximately
$1.8&nbsp;billion in annual savings through a combination of changes in
wages, benefits and work rules. In April&nbsp;2003, American reached
agreements with its three unions and also implemented various
changes in the pay plans and benefits for non-unionized personnel,
including officers and other management. The Labor Agreements and
Management Reductions resulted in $1.8 billion in annual savings including a workforce reduction of
approximately 9,300 jobs. In addition, the Company and American
reached concessionary agreements with certain vendors, lessors,
lenders and suppliers, resulting in approximately $200&nbsp;million in
annual cost savings. Generally, under the terms of these Vendor
Agreements, the Company or American received the benefit of lower
rates and charges for certain goods and services, and more
favorable rent and financing terms with respect to certain of its
aircraft.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Subsequent to the April&nbsp;2003 Labor Agreements the Company announced the Turnaround Plan. The
Turnaround Plan is the Company&#146;s strategic framework for returning
to sustained profitability and emphasizes: (i)&nbsp;lower costs, (ii)
an increased focus on what customers&#146; truly value and are prepared
to pay for, (iii)&nbsp;increased union and employee involvement in the
operation of the Company and (iv)&nbsp;the need for a more sound
balance sheet/financial structure.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In the latter part of 2003 and throughout 2004, the Company
continued to work &#150; under the basic tenets of the Turnaround Plan
&#150; with its unions and employees to identify and implement
additional initiatives designed to increase efficiencies and
revenues and reduce costs. These initiatives included: (i)&nbsp;the
return of under-used gate space and the consolidation of the
Company&#146;s terminal space, (ii)&nbsp;the de-peaking of its hub at Miami,
the reduction in the size of its St. Louis hub and the
simplification of its domestic operations, (iii)&nbsp;the acceleration
of the retirement of certain aircraft and the cancellation or
deferral of aircraft deliveries, (iv)&nbsp;the improvement of aircraft
utilization across its fleet and an increase in seating density on
certain fleet types, (v)&nbsp;the sale of certain non-core assets, (vi)
the expansion of its international network, where the Company
believes that higher revenue generating opportunities currently
exist, (vii)&nbsp;the implementation of an on-board food purchase
program and new fees for ticketing services and (viii)&nbsp;numerous
other initiatives.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>As part of its effort to build greater employee involvement, the
Company has worked to make its labor unions and its employees, its
business partners on the need for continuous improvement under the
Turnaround Plan. Among other things, the senior management of the
Company meets regularly with union officials to discuss the
Company&#146;s financial results as well as the competitive landscape.
These discussions include: (i)&nbsp;the Company&#146;s cost reduction and
revenue enhancement initiatives and (ii)&nbsp;a review of initiatives,
in-place or contemplated, at other airlines and the impact of
those initiatives on the Company&#146;s competitive posture.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Company&#146;s ability to become profitable and its ability to continue to fund its obligations on
an ongoing basis will depend on a number of factors, some of which are largely beyond the Company&#146;s
control. Some of the risk factors that affect the Company&#146;s business and financial results are
discussed in the Risk Factors found at the end of this Item&nbsp;7. As the Company seeks to improve its
financial condition, it must continue to take steps to generate additional revenues and
significantly reduce its costs. Although the Company has a number of initiatives underway to
address the cost and revenue challenges, the ultimate success of these initiatives is not known at
this time and cannot be assured. It will be very difficult, absent continued restructuring of its
operations, for the Company to continue to fund its obligations on an ongoing basis or to become
profitable if the overall industry revenue environment does not improve and fuel prices remain at
historically high levels for an extended period.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">21
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Cash, Short-Term Investments, Restricted Assets and Deposits</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had $2.9&nbsp;billion in unrestricted cash and short-term investments
and $478&nbsp;million in restricted cash and short-term investments.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Significant Indebtedness and Future Financing </B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During 2002, 2003 and 2004, in addition to refinancing its $834&nbsp;million credit facility (see
discussion in Note 6 to the consolidated financial statements), the Company raised an aggregate of
approximately $6.0&nbsp;billion of financing, mostly to fund capital commitments (mainly for aircraft
and ground properties) and operating losses. As of the date of this Form&nbsp;10-K, the Company believes
that it should have sufficient liquidity to fund its operations for the foreseeable future,
including repayment of debt and capital leases, capital expenditures and other contractual
obligations. However, to maintain sufficient liquidity as the Company continues to implement its
restructuring and cost reduction initiatives, and because the Company has significant debt
obligations maturing in the next several years, as well as substantial pension funding obligations,
the Company will need access to additional funding. The Company&#146;s possible financing sources
primarily include: (i)&nbsp;a limited amount of additional secured aircraft debt (a very large majority
of the Company&#146;s owned aircraft, including virtually all of the Company&#146;s Section&nbsp;1110-eligible
aircraft, are encumbered) or sale-leaseback transactions involving owned aircraft, (ii)&nbsp;debt
secured by new aircraft deliveries, (iii)&nbsp;debt secured by other assets, (iv)&nbsp;securitization of
future operating receipts, (v)&nbsp;the sale or monetization of certain assets, (vi)&nbsp;unsecured debt and
(vii)&nbsp;equity and/or equity-like securities. However, the availability and level of these financing
sources cannot be assured, particularly in light of the Company&#146;s and American&#146;s reduced credit
ratings, high fuel prices, historically weak revenues and the financial difficulties being
experienced in the airline industry. The inability of the Company to obtain additional funding
would have a material negative impact on the ability of the Company to sustain its operations over
the long-term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Company&#146;s substantial indebtedness could have important consequences. For example, it could
(i)&nbsp;limit the Company&#146;s ability to obtain additional financing for working capital, capital
expenditures, acquisitions and general corporate purposes, or adversely affect the terms on which
such financing could be obtained; (ii)&nbsp;require the Company to dedicate a substantial portion of its
cash flow from operations to payments on its indebtedness, thereby reducing the funds available for
other purposes; (iii)&nbsp;make the Company more vulnerable to economic downturns; (iv)&nbsp;limit its
ability to withstand competitive pressures and reduce its flexibility in responding to changing
business and economic conditions; and (v)&nbsp;limit the Company&#146;s flexibility in planning for, or
reacting to, changes in its business and the industry in which it operates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Credit Ratings </B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">AMR&#146;s and American&#146;s credit ratings are significantly below investment grade. Additional reductions
in AMR&#146;s or American&#146;s credit ratings could further increase its borrowing or other costs and
further restrict the availability of future financing.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Credit Facility Covenants</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On December&nbsp;17, 2004, American refinanced its $834&nbsp;million bank credit facility, which was
scheduled to mature in December&nbsp;2005. The total amount of the new credit facility is $850&nbsp;million,
all of which has been borrowed by American. The new credit facility consists of a $600&nbsp;million
senior secured revolving credit facility, with a final maturity on June&nbsp;17, 2009, and a $250
million term loan facility, with a final maturity on December&nbsp;17, 2010 (the Revolving Facility and
the Term Loan Facility, respectively, and collectively, the Credit Facility). American&#146;s
obligations under the Credit Facility are guaranteed by AMR.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">22
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Credit Facility contains a covenant requiring American to maintain, as defined, unrestricted
cash, unencumbered short term investments and amounts available for drawing under committed
revolving credit facilities of not less than $1.5&nbsp;billion for each quarterly period through
September&nbsp;30, 2005 and $1.25&nbsp;billion for each quarterly period thereafter. In addition, the Credit
Facility contains a covenant requiring AMR to maintain a ratio of cash flow (defined as
consolidated net income, before interest expense (less capitalized interest), income taxes,
depreciation and amortization and rentals, adjusted for certain gains or losses and non-cash items)
to fixed charges (comprising interest expense (less capitalized interest) and rentals) of at least
the amount specified below for each period of four consecutive quarters ending on the dates set
forth below:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">American and AMR were in compliance with these covenants as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and expect to be
able to continue to comply with these covenants, but there are no assurances that they will be able
to do so through the expiration of the facility. Failure to comply with these covenants would
result in a default under the Credit Facility which &#151; if the Company did not take steps to obtain
a waiver of, or otherwise mitigate, the default &#151; could result in a default under a significant
amount of the Company&#146;s other debt.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Note 6 to the consolidated financial statements for more information regarding the Credit
Facility.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">23
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Other Operating and Investing Activities</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Company&#146;s cash flow from operating activities improved in 2004. Net cash provided by operating
activities during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 was $717&nbsp;million, an increase of $116&nbsp;million
over 2003. Net cash provided by operating activities in 2003 included the receipt of a $572&nbsp;million
federal income tax refund and the receipt of $358&nbsp;million from the U.S. government under the
Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act (the Appropriations Act), offset by $521&nbsp;million
of redemption payments under operating leases for special facility revenue bonds. The Company does
not expect to receive significant additional federal income tax refunds.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Capital expenditures during 2004 were $1.0&nbsp;billion and included the acquisition of 36 Embraer 145
and six Bombardier CRJ-700 aircraft.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During 2003, the Company sold its interests in Worldspan, a computer reservations company, and
Hotwire, a discount travel website. The Company received $180&nbsp;million in cash and a $39&nbsp;million
promissory note for its interest in Worldspan. It received $84&nbsp;million in cash, $80&nbsp;million of
which was recognized as a gain, for its interest in Hotwire. In addition, during 2003, the Company
sold a portion of its interest in Orbitz, a travel planning website, in connection with an Orbitz
initial public offering and a secondary offering resulting in total proceeds of $65&nbsp;million, and a
gain of $70&nbsp;million.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During 2004, the Company sold its remaining interest in Orbitz resulting in total proceeds of $185
million and a gain of $146&nbsp;million.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Working Capital</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">AMR (principally American) historically operates with a working capital deficit, as do most other
airline companies. In addition, the Company has historically relied heavily on external financing
to fund capital expenditures. More recently, the Company has also relied on external financing to
fund operating losses.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Off Balance Sheet Arrangements</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">American has determined that it holds a significant variable interest in, but is not the primary
beneficiary of, certain trusts that are the lessors under 87 of its aircraft operating leases.
These leases contain a fixed price purchase option, which allows American to purchase the aircraft
at a predetermined price on a specified date. However, American does not guarantee the residual
value of the aircraft. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, future lease payments required under these leases
totaled $2.9&nbsp;billion.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Special facility revenue bonds have been issued by certain municipalities primarily to purchase
equipment and improve airport facilities that are leased by American and accounted for as operating
leases. Approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion of these bonds (with total future payments of approximately
$4.6&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2004) are guaranteed by American, AMR, or both. Approximately $532
million of these special facility revenue bonds contain mandatory tender provisions that require
American to make operating lease payments sufficient to repurchase the bonds at various times: $104
million in 2005, $28&nbsp;million in 2006, $100&nbsp;million in 2007, $188&nbsp;million in 2008 and $112&nbsp;million
in 2014. Although American has the right to remarket the bonds, there can be no assurance that
these bonds will be successfully remarketed. Any payments to redeem or purchase bonds that are not
remarketed would generally reduce existing rent leveling accruals or be considered prepaid facility
rentals and would reduce future operating lease commitments. Approximately $112&nbsp;million of special
facility revenue bonds with mandatory tender provisions were successfully remarketed in 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition, the Company has other operating leases, primarily for aircraft, with total future
lease payments of $4.9&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. Entering into aircraft leases allows the
Company to obtain aircraft without immediate cash outflows.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">24
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">As discussed in Note 5 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company reached concessionary
agreements with certain lessors in 2003. Certain of the Vendor Agreements provide that the
Company&#146;s obligations under the related lease revert to the original terms if certain events
(Events) occur prior to December&nbsp;31, 2005, including: (i)&nbsp;an event of default under the related
lease (which generally occurs only if a payment default occurs), (ii)&nbsp;an event of loss with respect
to the related aircraft, (iii)&nbsp;rejection by the Company of the lease under the provisions of
Chapter&nbsp;11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or (iv)&nbsp;the Company&#146;s filing for bankruptcy under Chapter&nbsp;7
of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. If any one of these Events were to occur, the Company would be
responsible for approximately $72&nbsp;million in additional operating lease payments and $59&nbsp;million in
additional payments related to capital leases as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. This amount will increase
to approximately $119&nbsp;million in operating lease payments and $111&nbsp;million in payments related to
capital leases prior to the expiration of the provision on December&nbsp;31, 2005. These amounts are
being accounted for as contingent rentals and will only be recognized if they become payable.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the commitments summarized above, the Company is required to make contributions to
its defined benefit pension plans. These contributions are required under the minimum funding
requirements of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA). The Company&#146;s estimated 2005
contributions to its defined benefit pension plans are approximately $310&nbsp;million. This estimate
reflects the provisions of the Pension Funding Equity Act of 2004. (The effect of the Pension
Funding Equity Act was to defer a portion of the minimum required contributions that would have
been due for the 2004 and 2005 plan years.) Due to uncertainties regarding significant assumptions
involved in estimating future required contributions to its defined benefit pension plans, such as
interest rate levels, the amount and timing of asset returns, and the impact of proposed
legislation, the Company is not able to reasonably estimate its future required contributions
beyond 2005. However, based on the current regulatory environment and market conditions, the
Company expects that its 2006 minimum required contributions will exceed its 2005 expected
contributions.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Results of Operations</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">AMR&#146;s net loss in 2004 was $761&nbsp;million, or $4.74 per share, an improvement of $467&nbsp;million over
AMR&#146;s net loss in 2003 of $1.2&nbsp;billion, or $7.76 per share. The year-over-year improvement in the
Company&#146;s 2004 operating results reflects the benefit of the cost reduction initiatives in the
Company&#146;s restructuring program, which is described above, dampened by the weak revenue environment
and the increase in fuel costs. The Company&#146;s 2004 results include a $146&nbsp;million gain on the sale
of the Company&#146;s remaining investment in Orbitz and $11&nbsp;million in special charges. The Company&#146;s
2003 results include several special items which are discussed in detail in the notes to the
consolidated financial statements, including (i) $358&nbsp;million in security cost reimbursements
received under the Appropriations Act (see Note 2 to the consolidated financial statements), (ii)
$407&nbsp;million in special charges (see Note 2 to the consolidated financial statements), (iii) $150
million in gains on the sale of the Company&#146;s investments in Hotwire and Orbitz (see Note 3 to the
consolidated financial statements) and (iv)&nbsp;a $164&nbsp;million reduction in previously accrued federal
income taxes and related interest. In addition, the Company did not record a tax benefit
associated with its 2004 or 2003 losses.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">26
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Revenues</B></FONT><BR><BR>
<B><I>2004 Compared to 2003 </I></B>The Company&#146;s revenues increased approximately $1.2&nbsp;billion, or 6.9
percent, to $18.6&nbsp;billion. American&#146;s passenger revenues increased by 4.8&nbsp;percent, or $689&nbsp;million,
on a capacity (available seat mile) (ASM)&nbsp;increase of 5.3&nbsp;percent. American&#146;s passenger load
factor increased 2.0 points to 74.8&nbsp;percent while passenger revenue yield per passenger mile
decreased by 3.1&nbsp;percent to 11.54 cents. This resulted in a decrease in passenger revenue per
available seat mile (RASM)&nbsp;of 0.5&nbsp;percent to 8.63 cents. In 2004, American derived approximately 66
percent of its passenger revenues from domestic operations and approximately 34&nbsp;percent from
international operations. Following is additional information regarding American&#146;s domestic and
international RASM and capacity:


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="60%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Company&#146;s Regional Affiliates include two wholly owned subsidiaries, American Eagle Airlines,
Inc. and Executive Airlines, Inc. (collectively, AMR Eagle), and two independent carriers with
which American has capacity purchase agreements, Trans States Airlines, Inc. (Trans States) and
Chautauqua Airlines, Inc. (Chautauqua).



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Regional Affiliates&#146; passenger revenues, which are based on industry standard proration agreements
for flights connecting to American flights, increased $357&nbsp;million, or 23.5&nbsp;percent, to $1.9
billion as a result of increased capacity and load factors. Regional Affiliates&#146; traffic increased
32.0&nbsp;percent to 7.3&nbsp;billion revenue passenger miles (RPMs), while capacity increased 26.0&nbsp;percent
to 10.8&nbsp;billion ASMs, resulting in a 3.0 point increase in passenger load factor to 67.2&nbsp;percent.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Cargo revenues increased 12.0&nbsp;percent, or $67&nbsp;million, primarily due to a 10.2&nbsp;percent increase in
cargo ton miles.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>2003 Compared to 2002 </I></B>The Company&#146;s revenues were relatively flat year-over-year, increasing
approximately $20&nbsp;million, or 0.1&nbsp;percent, to $17.4&nbsp;billion. During the first four months of 2003,
yields (passenger revenue per available seat mile) and load factors were down year-over-year, due
to the impact of the war in Iraq and SARS. In the latter part of the year, both yields and load
factors improved year-over-year, as the impact of the war in Iraq and SARS faded, and the U.S.
economy began recovering. However, even with those improvements, the Company&#146;s unit revenues and
yield remained depressed relative to historical measures.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">For the full year, American&#146;s passenger revenues decreased by 0.7&nbsp;percent, or $108&nbsp;million, to
$14.3&nbsp;billion, on a capacity decrease of 4.1&nbsp;percent to 165&nbsp;billion ASMs. American&#146;s passenger
load factor increased 2.1 points to 72.8&nbsp;percent and passenger revenue yield per passenger mile
increased by 0.4&nbsp;percent, or 0.05 cents, to 11.91 cents, driving American&#146;s RASM up by 3.3&nbsp;percent,
or 0.28 cents, to 8.67 cents. In 2003, American derived approximately 70&nbsp;percent of its passenger
revenues from domestic operations and approximately 30&nbsp;percent from international operations.
Following is additional information regarding American&#146;s domestic and international RASM and
capacity:

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">27
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In 2003, American had capacity purchase agreements with Chautauqua and Trans States for the full
year. In 2002, American had a capacity purchase agreement with Chautauqua for the full year and a
capacity purchase agreement with Trans States beginning in November&nbsp;2002.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Regional Affiliates&#146; passenger revenues increased $88&nbsp;million, or 6.1&nbsp;percent, to $1.5&nbsp;billion as a
result of increased capacity and load factors. Regional Affiliates&#146; traffic increased 20.5
percent, or 940&nbsp;million RPMs, to 5.5&nbsp;billion RPMs, while capacity increased 18.6&nbsp;percent, or 1.3
billion ASMs, to 8.6&nbsp;billion ASMs. This is somewhat offset by the elimination, in 2003, of a fee,
paid to AMR Eagle by American, for passengers connecting to American flights.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Operating
Expenses</B></FONT><BR><BR>

<B><I>2004 Compared to 2003 </I></B>The Company&#146;s total operating expenses increased 2.8&nbsp;percent, or $505
million, to $18.8&nbsp;billion in 2004 compared to 2003. American&#146;s mainline operating expenses per ASM
in 2004 decreased 4.1&nbsp;percent compared to 2003 to 9.73 cents. This decrease in operating expenses
per ASM is due primarily to the American&#146;s cost savings initiatives and occurred despite the
benefit in 2003 of the receipt of a grant from the U.S. government and a 38.5&nbsp;percent increase in
American&#146;s price per gallon of fuel (net of the impact of fuel hedging) in 2004 relative to 2003.

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade color="#000000">

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(a)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Wages, salaries and benefits decreased due to lower wage rates and reduced
headcount primarily as a result of the Labor Agreements and Management Reductions,
discussed in the Company&#146;s 2003 Form 10-K, which became effective in the second quarter
of 2003. This decrease was offset to some degree by increased headcount related to
capacity increases.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(b)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Aircraft fuel expense increased due to a 38.7&nbsp;percent increase in the Company&#146;s
price per gallon of fuel (net of the impact of fuel hedging) and a 3.3&nbsp;percent increase
in the Company&#146;s fuel consumption.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(c)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Maintenance, materials and repairs increased primarily due to increased aircraft
utilization, the benefit from retiring aircraft subsiding and increases in contractual
rates in certain flight hour agreements for outsourced aircraft engine maintenance.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(d)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Aircraft rentals decreased primarily due to the removal of leased aircraft from the
fleet in the second half of 2003 as part of the Company&#146;s restructuring initiatives and
concessionary agreements with certain lessors, which reduced future lease payment
amounts and resulted in the conversion of 30 operating leases to capital leases in the
second quarter of 2003.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(e)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Special charges for 2004 included (i)&nbsp;the reversal of reserves previously
established for aircraft return costs of $20&nbsp;million, facility exit costs of $21
million and employee severance of $11&nbsp;million, (ii) $21&nbsp;million in aircraft charges and
(iii) $42&nbsp;million in employee charges. Special charges for 2003 are described on the
following page. See a further discussion of Special charges in Note 2 to the
consolidated financial statements.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(f)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">U.S. government grant for 2003 reflects the reimbursement of security service fees
from the U.S. government under the Appropriations Act.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">28
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Effective January 1, 2005, in order to more accurately reflect the expected useful life of its aircraft, the Company changed its estimate of the depreciable lives
of certain American aircraft types from 25 to 30 years. The Company expects this change in estimate to result in a decrease in annual depreciation expense of approximately $100 million in 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>2003 Compared to 2002 </I></B>The Company&#146;s operating expenses decreased 11.9&nbsp;percent, or $2.5&nbsp;billion,
to $18.3&nbsp;billion and American&#146;s mainline operating expenses per ASM decreased 8.9&nbsp;percent to 10.15
cents, including the impact of special charges and the U.S. government grant. The decrease in
operating expenses and operating expenses per ASM is largely due to the Company&#146;s cost savings
initiatives coupled with security cost reimbursements from the U.S. government and a decrease in
special charges.

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade color="#000000">

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(a)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Wages, salaries and benefits decreased due to lower wage rates and reduced
headcount primarily as a result of the Labor Agreements and Management Reductions,
effective in the second quarter of 2003.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(b)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Aircraft fuel expense increased due to a 15.1&nbsp;percent increase in the Company&#146;s
price per gallon of fuel (net of the impact of fuel hedging), somewhat offset by a 5.5
percent decrease in the Company&#146;s fuel consumption.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(c)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Commissions, booking fees and credit card expense decreased due primarily to
commission structure changes implemented in March&nbsp;2002.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(d)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Maintenance, materials and repairs decreased due primarily to a decrease in
airframe and engine volumes at the Company&#146;s maintenance bases resulting from a variety
of factors, including the retirement and temporary grounding of aircraft and a decrease
in the numbers of flights.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(e)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Aircraft rentals decreased due primarily to the removal of leased aircraft from the
fleet in prior periods as part of the Company&#146;s restructuring initiatives and
concessionary agreements with certain lessors, which reduced future lease payment
amounts and resulted in the conversion of 30 operating leases to capital leases.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(f)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Food service decreased due primarily to a decrease in the number of departures and
passengers boarded and simplification of catering services.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(g)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Other operating expenses decreased primarily due to decreases in (i)&nbsp;data
processing expenses of $87&nbsp;million due primarily to introducing further efficiencies
into data processing environments resulting in reduced consumption, and negotiating
more favorable terms with vendors; (ii)&nbsp;travel and incidental costs of $61&nbsp;million due
primarily to decreased overnight stays for pilots and flight attendants as a result of
changes in the scheduling of flights, lower average hotel rates, work rule changes and
lower per diems; (iii)&nbsp;insurance costs of $44&nbsp;million due primarily to lower premiums,
(iv)&nbsp;security costs of $31&nbsp;million due primarily to the assumption of certain security
services by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA)&nbsp;and the suspension of
security services payments to the TSA from June&nbsp;1, 2003 to September&nbsp;30, 2003 and (v)
contract maintenance work that American performs for other airlines of $29&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">29
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">





<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(h)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Special charges for 2003 included approximately (i) $341&nbsp;million in aircraft charges
offset by a $20&nbsp;million credit to adjust prior accruals, (ii) $92&nbsp;million in employee
charges, (iii) $62&nbsp;million in facility exit costs and a (iv) $68&nbsp;million gain resulting
from a transaction involving 33 of the Company&#146;s Fokker 100 aircraft and related debt.
Special charges for 2002 included approximately (i) $658&nbsp;million related to aircraft
charges, (ii) $57&nbsp;million in employee charges and (iii) $3&nbsp;million in facility charges.
See a further discussion of Special charges in Note 2 to the consolidated financial
statements.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(i)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">U.S. government grant includes a $358&nbsp;million benefit recognized for the
reimbursement of security service fees from the U.S. government under the
Appropriations Act in 2003. See a further discussion of U.S. government grant in Note 2
to the consolidated financial statements.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Other
Income (Expense)</B></FONT><BR><BR>

Other income (expense)&nbsp;consists of interest income and expense, interest capitalized and
miscellaneous &#151; net.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>2004 Compared to 2003 </I></B>Interest income increased $11&nbsp;million, or 20.0&nbsp;percent, to $66&nbsp;million due
primarily to increases in short-term investment balances and interest rates. Interest expense
increased $168&nbsp;million, or 23.9&nbsp;percent, to $871&nbsp;million resulting primarily from the increase in
the Company&#146;s long-term debt coupled with increases in interest rates, and an $84&nbsp;million reduction
in interest expense in 2003 related to the agreement reached with the IRS discussed below.
Miscellaneous-net for 2004 includes a $146&nbsp;million gain on the sale of the Company&#146;s remaining
interest in Orbitz.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>2003 Compared to 2002 </I></B>Interest income decreased $16&nbsp;million, or 22.5&nbsp;percent, to $55&nbsp;million due
primarily to decreases in interest rates. Interest expense increased $18&nbsp;million, or 2.6&nbsp;percent,
to $703&nbsp;million resulting primarily from the increase in the Company&#146;s long-term debt, offset by an
$84&nbsp;million reduction in interest expense related to the agreement reached with the IRS discussed
below. Interest capitalized decreased $15&nbsp;million, or 17.4&nbsp;percent, to $71&nbsp;million due primarily
to a decrease in purchase deposits for flight equipment. Miscellaneous-net increased $115&nbsp;million
to $113&nbsp;million, due primarily to an $80&nbsp;million gain on the sale of the Company&#146;s investment in
Hotwire and a $70&nbsp;million gain related to an initial public offering by Orbitz, offset by the
write-down of certain investments held by the Company during the first quarter of 2003.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><B>Income Tax Benefit</B></FONT>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>2004 </B>The Company did not record a net tax benefit associated with its 2004 losses due to the
Company providing a valuation allowance, as discussed in Note 8 to the consolidated financial
statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>2003 </B>The Company did not record a net tax benefit associated with its 2003 losses due to the
Company providing a valuation allowance. Additionally, in 2003, the Company reached an agreement
with the IRS covering tax years 1990 through 1995. As a result of this agreement, the Company
recorded an $80&nbsp;million tax benefit to reduce previously accrued income tax liabilities and an $84
million reduction in interest expense to reduce previously accrued interest related to the accrued
income tax liabilities.




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">30
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Outlook </B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Company expects to incur a loss in the first quarter of 2005. However, the size of the loss is
uncertain due to external factors beyond the Company&#146;s control such as fuel prices and the revenue
environment. The Company currently expects first quarter mainline unit costs to be approximately
9.9 cents.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Capacity for American&#146;s mainline jet operations is expected to be essentially flat in the first
quarter of 2005 compared to the first quarter of 2004 with domestic capacity decreasing about four
percent and international capacity increasing about twelve percent. Capacity for American&#146;s
mainline jet operations is expected to increase about 2.6&nbsp;percent for the full year 2005 compared
to the full year 2004, with domestic capacity decreasing about one percent and international
capacity increasing about eleven percent.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U><B>Other Information</B></U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Environmental Matters </B>Subsidiaries of AMR have been notified of potential liability with regard
to several environmental cleanup sites and certain airport locations. At sites where remedial
litigation has commenced, potential liability is joint and several. AMR&#146;s alleged volumetric
contributions at all but one of these sites are minimal compared to others. AMR does not expect
these matters, individually or collectively, to have a material impact on its results of
operations, financial position or liquidity. Additional information is included in Part C of Item
1 and Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">31
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates </B>The preparation of the Company&#146;s financial statements
in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates
and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and
accompanying notes. The Company believes its estimates and assumptions are reasonable; however,
actual results and the timing of the recognition of such amounts could differ from those estimates.
The Company has identified the following critical accounting policies and estimates used by
management in the preparation of the Company&#146;s financial statements: accounting for long-lived
assets, passenger revenue, frequent flyer program, pensions and other postretirement benefits, and
income taxes.




<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt"><I>Long-lived assets &#150; </I>The Company has approximately $20&nbsp;billion of long-lived assets as of
December&nbsp;31, 2004, including approximately $19&nbsp;billion related to flight equipment and other
fixed assets. In addition to the original cost of these assets, their recorded value is
impacted by a number of policy elections made by the Company, including estimated useful lives
and salvage values. In accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;144,
&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148; (SFAS 144), the Company
records impairment charges on long-lived assets used in operations when events and
circumstances indicate that the assets may be impaired, the undiscounted cash flows estimated
to be generated by those assets are less than the carrying amount of those assets and the net
book value of the assets exceeds their estimated fair value. In making these determinations,
the Company uses certain assumptions, including, but not limited to: (i)&nbsp;estimated fair value
of the assets and (ii)&nbsp;estimated future cash flows expected to be generated by these assets,
which are based on additional assumptions such as asset utilization, length of service and
estimated salvage values. A change in the Company&#146;s fleet plan has been the primary indicator
that has resulted in an impairment charge. The Company recorded impairment charges related to
its Fokker 100, Saab 340 and ATR 42 aircraft in 2002. In 2003, the Company recorded an
impairment charge related to its Airbus A300 aircraft as a result of accelerating the planned
retirement of this fleet. See Notes 1 and 2 to the consolidated financial statements for
additional information with respect to these charges and each of the policies and assumptions
used by the Company which affect the recorded values of long-lived assets.



<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt"><I>Passenger revenue &#150; </I>Passenger ticket sales are initially recorded as a component of Air
traffic liability. Revenue derived from ticket sales is recognized at the time service is
provided. However, due to various factors, including the industry&#146;s pricing structure and
interline agreements throughout the industry, certain amounts are recognized in revenue using
estimates regarding both the timing of the revenue recognition and the amount of revenue to be
recognized, including breakage. These estimates are generally based upon the evaluation of
historical trends, including the use of regression analysis and other methods to model the
outcome of future events based on the Company&#146;s historical experience, and are recognized at
the time of departure. The Company&#146;s estimation techniques have been applied consistently from
year to year. However, due to changes in the Company&#146;s ticket refund policy and changes in
the travel profile of customers, historical trends may not be representative of future
results.



<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt"><I>Frequent flyer program &#150; </I>American uses the incremental cost method to account for the portion
of its frequent flyer liability incurred when AAdvantage members earn mileage credits by
flying on American or American Eagle. American&#146;s frequent flyer liability is accrued each
time a member accumulates sufficient mileage in his or her account to claim the lowest level
of free travel award (25,000 miles) and the award is expected to be used for free travel.
American includes fuel, food, and reservations/ticketing costs in the calculation of
incremental cost. These estimates are generally updated based upon the Company&#146;s 12-month
historical average of such costs. American also accrues a frequent flyer liability for the
mileage credits that are expected to be used for travel on participating airlines based on
historical usage patterns and contractual rates.



<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt">Revenue earned from selling AAdvantage miles to other companies is recognized in two
components. The first component represents the revenue for air transportation sold and is
valued at current market rates. This revenue is deferred and recognized over the period the
mileage is expected to be used, which is currently estimated to be 28&nbsp;months. The second
revenue component, representing the marketing products sold and administrative costs
associated with operating the AAdvantage program, is recognized immediately.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">32
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">


<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt">At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, American estimated that approximately ten million free travel
awards were expected to be redeemed for free travel on American and American Eagle. In making
the estimate of free travel awards, American has excluded mileage in inactive accounts,
mileage related to accounts that have not yet reached the lowest level of free travel award,
and mileage in active accounts that have reached the lowest level of free travel award but
which are not expected to ever be redeemed for free travel on American or participating
airlines. The Company&#146;s total liability for future AAdvantage award redemptions for free,
discounted or upgraded travel on American, American Eagle or participating airlines as well as
unrecognized revenue from selling AAdvantage miles to other companies was approximately $1.4
billion and $1.2&nbsp;billion (and is recorded as a component of Air traffic liability in the
consolidated balance sheets), representing 19.6&nbsp;percent and 18.8&nbsp;percent of AMR&#146;s total
current liabilities, at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.



<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt">The number of free travel awards used for travel on American and American Eagle in 2004 and
2003 was 2.6&nbsp;million and 2.5&nbsp;million, respectively, representing approximately 7.5&nbsp;percent and
7.8&nbsp;percent of passengers boarded, respectively. The Company believes displacement of revenue
passengers is minimal given the Company&#146;s load factors, its ability to manage frequent flyer
seat inventory, and the relatively low ratio of free award usage to total passengers boarded.



<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt">Changes to the percentage of the amount of revenue deferred, deferred recognition period,
percentage of awards expected to be redeemed for travel on participating airlines, cost per
mile estimates or the minimum award level accrued could have a significant impact on the
Company&#146;s revenues or incremental cost accrual in the year of the change as well as in future
years.



<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt"><I>Pensions and other postretirement benefits </I>&#150; The Company&#146;s pension and other postretirement
benefit costs and liabilities are calculated using various actuarial assumptions and
methodologies. The Company uses certain assumptions including, but not limited to, the
selection of the: (i)&nbsp;discount rate, (ii)&nbsp;expected return on plan assets, and (iii)&nbsp;expected
health care cost trend rate.



<P align="left" style="margin-left:3%; font-size: 10pt">These assumptions as of December&nbsp;31 were:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="94%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">2004</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">2003</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Discount rate</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">6.00</TD>
    <TD nowrap>%</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="right">6.25</TD>
    <TD nowrap>%</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Expected return on plan assets</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">9.00</TD>
    <TD nowrap>%</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">9.00</TD>
    <TD nowrap>%</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Expected health care cost trend rate:</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="right">10.0</TD>

    <TD nowrap>%</TD>

<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:45px; text-indent:-15px">Ultimate (2010)</DIV></TD>

    <TD align="right">4.5</TD>
    <TD nowrap>%</TD>
